Award.AwardTitle: Intermediate Energy Nuclear Physics with Electromagnetic Probes at Jefferson Lab
Award.AbstractNarration:
The present NSF grant primarily funds the RPI group's participation in the the physics program of the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility, where it is a member of the CLAS Collaboration. The experimental program's goal is to learn about and image the composition of protons and neutrons - generically called nucleons - which comprise nearly all the currently visible matter in the universe. Nucleons are composed of very complicated arrays of quarks immersed in the strong nuclear fields called gluons.

The main instrument used is the CLAS spectrometer, inside of which a beam of electrons from the Jefferson Lab accelerator impinges upon a target of protons. Most often the target is in the form of liquid hydrogen atoms. The experiments in which the RPI group are focusing are those in which an electron in the beam strikes and scatters off a proton and part of the energy imparted to the proton produces either a single photon (a quantum of electromagnetic radiation), or a single meson, which is a particle consisting of a quark and antimatter quark pair. By studying this reaction as the imparted energy and direction of the scattered electron is varied, the group seeks to obtain a three dimensional image of the distributions of the quarks in the proton, which has never yet been accomplished.

During this grant period the group will continue work on a new CLAS spectrometer, called CLAS12, which is part of the ongoing project at Jefferson Lab to double the energy of the electron beam. The component of the CLAS12 spectrometer on which the RPI is specifically contributing is called a high threshold Cherenkov counter (HTCC), which will be used to identify the scattered electrons. This is in addition to the more general role the Principal Investigator plays in the upgrade as chairman of the CLAS12 steering committee.

RPI is a technology based university whose primary goal is to prepare future scientists and engineers for the most advanced technological demands of society. The complexity of the experiments in this research require the development and use of the most advanced scientific equipment and computational techniques. RPI graduate and undergraduate students, as well as post-doctoral associates, participate one way or another in programs such as this, and in the present case directly carry out most of the direct work on the experimental program, enabling them to become the scientific and engineering leaders of a technologically competitive society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goals for this research were to illucidate the structure of the nucleons in terms of their fundamental constituent quarks and gluon, or "parton", fields. This was done primarily by scattering precisely controlled high energy electrons from protons such that they interact with  these constituent partons and thereby image their positions and motions within the proton. As a result of such a collision, some of the electron's energy may be converted into quanta of electromagnetic radiation (photons), in a reaction known as deeply virtual Compton scattering ( DVCS), or small particles of matter, known as mesons, in a reaction known as deeply virtual meson production ( DVMP). In the reported experiments, these "secondary" produced objects were detected and their distributions in angle and energy recorded. The resulting distributions were then analyzed to extract the information we seek about the parton distributions which we seek.

Figure 1 schematically shows such a reaction in which the the scattered electron produces a  " γ" (photon) or "η" (eta) or "π" (pi) meson  following the scattering of an electron from a down (d) or up (u) quark in the proton.

Data were obtained for  γ  (DVCS), and ,  η  and π  (DVMP) production. The DVCS distributions were analyzed by our collaborators to yield tomographic distributions of quarks. Figure 2 shows the result of their analysis.

Since the η  and π are composed of  different combinations of u and d quarks, the data can be deconvoluted to give an idea  of the distributions of the individual u  and d quarks.  Figure 3 shows the result of a (very naive)  "tomagraphic" deconvolution of the measured distributions for u and d quarks separately. It shows the transverse extent of the "transversely polarized nucleons" vs   xB ( a quantity which is related to the "longitudinal" momentum of the quark). It appears to indicate that for transversely polarized quarks the u quarks appears to be distributed more narrowly than the d quarks relative to the incident electromagnetic probe.

These results are quite schematic, especially for the meson production (Fig. 3), where the statistical errors in measurement are rather large, but they represent an initial attempt to analyze our  data and understand the 3-dimensional tomagraphic distributions of the quarks with  protons and neutrons. The experimental results obtained, so far, are currently undergoing analysis to improve our confidence in the extracted information.
